timeline.bodyText: Is reference equality what we want here?
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: If the person is assigned to this unit, we want it selected. A comparison of the unit id should do that perfectly. I'm pretty sure it is correct, unless I'm missing something both in code and testing.
replies.author: Windchild292

replies.bodyText: You're currently testing if the person's unit ID points to the same location in memory as the unit's ID. You likely intended this to compare the value of the IDs, right? Outside of int, boolean, float, and other primitive types, you should be using a.equals(b) or Objects.equals(a, b).
replies.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: Fixed, and I always forget where the line is drawn for .equals instead of == comparisons
replies.author: Windchild292

timeline.bodyText: Is reference equality what we want here?
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

timeline.bodyText: Is reference equality what we want here?
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

timeline.bodyText: I'll stop asking about that reference equality, but there's more of these.
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: Fourteen in total.
replies.author: Windchild292

timeline.bodyText: Is this null safe?
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: Bloodname defaults to "", so it does not need to be.
replies.author: Windchild292

timeline.bodyText: Should these be AUTOMATIC_FAIL?
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: No, because of modifiers these can be pushed below 13. It just makes it very rare, which I believe is the point. IIRC, @neoancient added this and should be able to comment?
replies.author: Windchild292

replies.bodyText: I wrote the bloodname generation code, but I didn't write this part, and I can't say for sure what the intention was. I'm not sure how we would end up in a situation where somebody was generated with a certain phenotypes and doesn't have the skills that go with the role, but I would say it should be automatic fail.
replies.author: neoancient

replies.bodyText: Sounds good, will have that updated shortly
replies.author: Windchild292

replies.bodyText: JavaDoc

timeline.bodyText: Can we get an example name for this area that this handles?
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText:
One potential case from our own random generation is:
Chan Juan St. Albans
One reason I'm adding this is to handle one of my D&D character's names:
The Right Honourable Terrwyn Owain ap Gwythyr Aberdinas von Hofen Penderyn III
replies.author: Windchild292

timeline.bodyText: Any reason this can't be an Enum? I loathe all of our random integers.
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: This is unimplemented (code that I'm thinking about for wave 2), but I'll add a note to myself to swap it to an enum (I personally like the integers instead of enums, but I know that's not a common view)
replies.author: Windchild292

replies.bodyText: I've removed the code from this PR
replies.author: Windchild292

timeline.bodyText: Based on this comment then is CampaignOptions storing the fraction or percentage? If Percentage that should be called out in the documentation for the option. Would be more obvious given the name "chance" to store it as a fraction and convert to a percentage when displaying.
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: It is saving as a percentage, we divide by 100 here for the fraction.
replies.author: Windchild292

replies.bodyText: Would you prefer switching to saving it divided by 100 @sixlettervariables?
replies.author: Windchild292

replies.bodyText:
I would find storing a fraction to be less confusing.
That being said, JavaDoc for the methods would provide those details and hopefully answer those questions.
replies.author: sixlettervariables

timeline.bodyText: I'm not so sure that'll help. I went through and rewrote this to use equals (as case is important in XML) and also a trie, the node name matching did not end up being a significant part of the work.
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: Just one of the performance ideas I was working on, I also found it didn't amount to much, but forgot to remove. Removed.
replies.author: Windchild292

timeline.bodyText: Why not just call this once at the very end?
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: Switched it over to do so
replies.author: Windchild292

timeline.bodyText: Is abilityString.length() == 0 not an option? (or size() == 0) ?
timeline.author: sixlettervariables

replies.bodyText: It is, swapped over to using abilityString.length() == 0
